# Summary of Article

**Article Title:** Americans Predict Challenging 2026 Across 13 Dimensions

**Source:** Gallup.com  
**Date:** January 5, 2026  
**Author:** Gallup, Inc.

## Key Facts and Statistics:

- **Survey Details:** Nationally representative web survey conducted December 1-14, 2025, via the probability-based Gallup Panel with 2,020 adults aged 18+. Margin of error: ±3 percentage points at 95% confidence level.

- **Overall Outlook:** Americans expect 2026 to be challenging, with majorities foreseeing negative outcomes in most of 13 measured dimensions (economic, political, societal, and international).

- **Stock Market Exception:** 55% believe the stock market will rise - the only aspect with majority-level positive prediction.

- **Most Pessimistic Areas:** Political cooperation, international disputes, China's power in the world, federal budget deficit, and economic prosperity.

- **Other Negative Expectations:** Clear majorities expect rising unemployment, taxes, prices, and crime rates, along with declining American power in the world.

- **Year-over-Year Comparison:** Predictions for 2026 are considerably more negative than for 2025, including:
  - Double-digit declines (11-18 percentage points) in positive predictions for: employment, taxes, economic prosperity, China's power, political cooperation, prices, and stock market
  - 5-9 point declines for: U.S. power in the world, federal budget deficit, international disputes, and crime rate

- **Partisan Differences:** 
  - Republicans: 52-83% predict positive outcomes for most aspects (exceptions: political cooperation at 17%, China's power declining at 48%)
  - Democrats: No more than 36% expect any positive situations
  - Independents: 54% predict stock market rise; 50% expect few labor strikes or declining Russian power

- **Mental Health Statistic:** 29% of U.S. adults describe their mental health as excellent, down 14 points from 2019 and the first reading below 30%.

## Relevance to Forecasting Question:

It contains no information about Tobago, the Tobago House of Assembly, Caribbean politics, or election disputes/reversals.
</Summary>

**A simple guide to the May elections in England, Scotland and Wales**
On Thursday, 7 May 2026, millions of voters in England, Scotland, and Wales will participate in a major set of elections, the largest since the 2024 general election. In England, 136 local councils will hold elections for approximately 5,000 seats, including 30 councils that were previously delayed to May 2027 but now proceed in May 2026 after a government U-turn prompted by legal challenges from Reform UK. Six mayoral contests are scheduled in Croydon, Hackney, Lewisham, Newham, Tower Hamlets, and Watford, while mayoral elections in Cumbria, Cheshire & Warrington, Greater Essex, Norfolk and Suffolk, Hampshire and the Solent, and Sussex and Brighton have been postponed until 2027 or 2028. Council elections use the first-past-the-post system, and councils are responsible for local services such as housing, education, and waste management amid ongoing funding crises. In Scotland, all 129 Members of the Scottish Parliament (MSPs) are up for re-election, with voters casting two ballots—one for a constituency MSP via first past the post and one for regional MSPs using proportional representation. The Scottish Parliament, established in 1999, governs areas like health, education, policing, and tax. In Wales, the 2026 Senedd election will expand the number of Members of the Senedd (MSs) from 60 to 96 across 16 new constituencies, with seats allocated proportionally. No party has ever won a majority in the Welsh Parliament, and the new system makes it highly unlikely that will change. The first minister is nominated by any MS and elected by the Senedd. Voter eligibility requires registration by 23:59 BST on 20 April 2026. In England, voters must be 18 and present valid photo ID (e.g., passport or driving licence) to vote in person; out-of-date ID is acceptable if the voter is still recognizable. Those without ID can apply for a free voter authority certificate by 17:00 BST on 28 April 2026. In Scotland and Wales, no ID is required for in-person voting. Postal and proxy votes must be renewed every three years, with deadlines at 17:00 BST on 21 April (postal) and 28 April (proxy) 2026.

**Assam Assembly Election 2026: Key Dates, Phases, and Political Outlook**
The Assam Legislative Assembly elections for 2026 are expected to be held in the first week of April 2026, with voting likely between April 3 and April 7, based on a minimum 25-day gap between the election announcement and voting as mandated by the Election Commission. The current assembly's term ends in May 2026, necessitating the formation of a new government beforehand. According to sources, the election is likely to be held in a single phase, unlike the three-phase voting in 2021. Assam has 126 assembly seats, and a majority requires at least 64 seats. The BJP-led NDA alliance, currently in power under Chief Minister Himanta Biswa Sarma, aims to secure 90 to 100 seats in this election, marking its third consecutive term. To counter anti-incumbency sentiment, the BJP plans to revoke tickets from 25–30 sitting MLAs and replace them with 25–30 new faces. Prime Minister Narendra Modi is expected to hold 8–10 rallies in the state post-announcement to strengthen the election atmosphere. Major opposition parties include the Indian National Congress, Asom Gana Parishad, and All India United Democratic Front, indicating a multi-cornered contest. The Election Commission’s official announcement is awaited, with the model code of conduct possibly coming into force in the first week of March 2026.

**National Assembly, INEC Set To Propose New Dates For 2027 Elections Amid Ramadan Fallout**
The National Assembly and the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) have agreed to move the 2027 Nigerian presidential election from the originally scheduled February 20, 2027, to January 16, 2027, and the governorship elections from March 6, 2027, to January 30, 2027, according to multiple sources within the electoral body and federal legislature. This shift follows widespread criticism from Muslim groups and political stakeholders, including former Vice President Atiku Abubakar and former presidential aide Bashir Ahmad, who argued that holding elections during the 2027 Ramadan period—projected to run from February 7 to March 8—would suppress Muslim voter turnout. The initial February date sparked controversy, prompting emergency consultations. A senior INEC official confirmed that the new proposal emerged after several meetings between INEC and legislative leadership, though the plan remains subject to formal adoption. The National Assembly suspended its harmonisation of the Electoral Act (Amendment) Bill and called an emergency plenary session for Tuesday, February 17, 2026, to address the election dates. The session, described as crucial, will precede further debate on other contentious provisions of the bill. If approved, January 16, 2027, would be among the earliest presidential election dates in Nigeria’s Fourth Republic.

**2027: N'Assembly eyes Jan 16 for presidential poll, suspends Electoral Bill harmonisation**
The Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) and the National Assembly have reportedly agreed to move Nigeria's 2027 presidential election to January 16, 2027, and governorship elections to January 30, 2027, reversing the previously scheduled February 20 and March 6 dates. This decision follows strong criticism from Muslim groups and political stakeholders who argued that the original February 20 date coincided with Ramadan (February 7–March 8, 2027), potentially suppressing voter participation. A senior INEC official confirmed the new dates, though a ranking senator cautioned the proposal remains subject to debate. The shift, if ratified, would compress campaign timelines and administrative preparations, marking a significant recalibration of the electoral calendar. The emergency plenary session of the National Assembly, reconvened on February 17, 2026, has suspended the harmonisation of the Electoral Act Amendment Bill to prioritize the election date review. The suspension reflects the prioritization of politically sensitive scheduling issues over technical legislative harmonisation. INEC acknowledged public concerns and stated it remains open to legislative intervention to ensure compliance with constitutional requirements while addressing inclusivity. The change could enhance Muslim voter turnout in northern states but may strain INEC’s logistics and party mobilisation. Broader reforms, including expediting election petition resolution and ensuring elections occur at least 185 days before incumbent terms end, are also under consideration. The convergence of religious, technological, and constitutional factors has placed the National Assembly and INEC at the center of a pivotal electoral reform moment.

**Sindaco, è il giorno del giudizio: Final ruling on Porto Viro mayoral election appeal**
Today, January 29, 2026, is the day of judgment for Porto Viro, as the Council of State is set to rule on an appeal filed by former mayoral candidate Stefano Permunian against the results of the municipal elections held on May 25–26, 2024. The elections ended with Mario Mantovan winning by a narrow margin of seven votes (2,530 to 2,523). Initially, only three ballots were formally contested in official records, but Permunian’s list expanded the challenge to include ballots marked with 'Thor' and 'Vigile'. The Veneto Regional Administrative Court (Tar) had previously rejected the appeal on October 2, 2024, ruling that the 'proof of resistance'—the threshold proving irregularities could have altered the outcome—was not met. Despite this, Permunian appealed to the Council of State, the highest administrative court in Italy, seeking annulment of the Tar’s decision, a re-examination of contested ballots, and, in a subordinate request, a re-vote in certain sections. The Mantovan administration has expressed confidence in the judiciary but criticized the financial and administrative costs of prolonged uncertainty. The Council of State’s decision will be final, with no further appeals allowed. If the appeal is dismissed, Mantovan’s victory becomes definitive. A partial acceptance might acknowledge minor irregularities without changing the outcome. Only if a recount alters the vote tally could Mantovan’s position be overturned. The most extreme outcome—annulling the election and imposing a commissioner-led administration with new elections—remains possible. Both Mantovan and Permunian have declared composure: Mantovan emphasized transparency and the waste of public resources, while Permunian defended the legal right to challenge results as a democratic duty, stating they will accept any verdict.

**Coahuila Unveils 2026 Electoral Calendar for State Legislature Elections**
The Instituto Electoral de Coahuila (IEC) has released the official calendar for the 2026 Local Ordinary Electoral Process, outlining key dates for the election of 25 local deputies to the state legislature. Although preliminary activities began in late 2025, the formal process starts in January 2026. Political parties may submit coalition agreements between January 2 and January 12, 2026, with the IEC announcing approved alliances by January 24, 2026. Independent candidates must collect citizen support from February 25 to March 16, 2026, while party internal processes and pre-campaigns run from March 1 to March 20, 2026. Candidate registrations will be accepted from April 25 to April 29, 2026, followed by document review and approval from April 30 to May 4, 2026. Campaigns will run from May 5 to June 3, 2026, after which a silence period begins on June 4, prohibiting political propaganda until Election Day. The election will be held on Sunday, June 7, 2026, with preliminary results (PREP) beginning that evening. District counts will occur from June 9 to June 13, 2026, and the state-wide count, including proportional representation and official validation, must conclude by June 14, 2026. The IEC has allocated 241 million pesos for political party activities during the process, involving 8 registered political parties in the state.

**National Assembly Election Process Begins in Nepal**
The National Assembly election process in Nepal has officially begun, starting today, January 17, 2026, at 10:00 AM, according to the Election Commission. Today's agenda includes the publication of the preliminary voter list. Individuals whose names are missing from the published list may submit applications to have their names included, request corrections, or file objections against registered voters between January 20, 2026, at 4:00 PM and January 21, 2026. The Commission will review all submitted applications and objections on January 21 and 22, 2026, and will publish the final voter list between 3:00 PM and 4:00 PM on January 22, 2026. Candidates may withdraw their nominations between January 27, 2026, at 10:00 AM and 1:00 PM. The final candidate list will be published between 1:00 PM and 2:00 PM on the same day. On January 28, 2026, from 10:00 AM to 1:00 PM, candidates will be assigned election symbols. Voting will take place on January 11, 2026, from 9:00 AM to 3:00 PM. The term of 19 National Assembly members elected in Falgun 2076 (2020) will end on February 20, 2026, with one member appointed by the President and the remaining 18 seats up for election. Elections are held every two years for one-third of the National Assembly seats. This election includes three seats from Koshi Province, four from Madhesh Province, two each from Bagmati and Gandaki Provinces, three from Lumbini Province, and two each from Karnali and Sudurpaschim Provinces.

**I Would Have Said NO to the US Radar"  --  Augustine Challenges Central Government Control**
Farley Augustine, Tobago Chief Secretary and member of the Tobago People's Party (TPP), criticized the installation of a US Marine Corps Ground/Air Task-Oriented Radar (G/ATOR) system at ANR Robinson International Airport, stating he would have rejected it had the Tobago House of Assembly (THA) had the authority to do so. Augustine revealed he first learned of the radar through social media, not official channels, and emphasized that while the system is intended for counter-narcotics surveillance and is non-offensive, the real issue lies in decision-making power: 'Tobago deserves more than information — we deserve a say.' He announced that a re-elected TPP government would initiate a referendum on Tobago's self-governance by mid-2026, potentially granting the island veto power over national security decisions affecting it. The radar has sparked public debate, with tourism stakeholders reporting declining bookings and critics highlighting a lack of transparency. Augustine dismissed claims that the radar makes Tobago a military target as 'fear-mongering,' reaffirming the island's neutral stance. The issue has become central to the 2026 THA election, framing it as a referendum on Tobago’s political future. The TPP currently holds a strong majority in the THA, and Augustine, the youngest Chief Secretary in Tobago’s history, is running for re-election on a platform of empowerment, accountability, and development.
